lessons.title: OOP without inheritance
lessons.interactiveContent:
As we've previously learned, OOP means we encapsulate related data and functions inside objects.

Make sure to pick class, followed by Person:.

lessons.title: OOP without inheritance is inefficient
lessons.interactiveContent:
When we create objects one by one we run into the problem of having duplicate code. How many greet() methods are there?

31

Make sure to pick 3.

lessons.title: The concept of inheritance
lessons.interactiveContent: We use inheritance to make our code efficient. Through inheritance, classes receive methods from other classes.

lessons.title: The concept of inheritance 2
lessons.interactiveContent: Inheritance lets us create classes that have different properties and behaviors without coding each one from scratch.

lessons.title: The concept of inheritance 3
lessons.interactiveContent: Here we see that the Child class is inheriting the Parent class because it's inside the parentheses after the class name.

lessons.title: Creating objects that inherit methods
lessons.interactiveContent:
Let's look at how a class can inherit methods from another. When defining the class we add parentheses with the class that we're inheriting.

Make sure to pick (, followed by Greetings, and finally ).

lessons.title: Calling inherited methods
lessons.interactiveContent:
The Person class can now use the Greeting's methods like its own. Try calling greet() as a method of person.

Make sure to pick . followed by greet and then (, ).

lessons.title: Setting methods directly
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can update how classes work by setting methods directly in the class. Define the charge method inside the Hybrid class.

Make sure to pick def followed by charge and then (, self, ), :.

lessons.title: Outro
lessons.interactiveContent: We've learned how flexible Python can be using inheritance. Next, we'll dive further into how classes inherit things.

lessons.title: Question 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of these describes inheritance?

Classes that inherit the functionality of another classClasses that only inherit variables from other classes

Classes that inherit the functionality of another class.

lessons.title: Question 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
How does inheritance make our OOP code more efficient?

Functions need to be set only onceProperties need to be set only once

Functions need to be set only once.

lessons.title: Question 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of these doesn't need to be inherited?

Methods used by only one objectMethods used by more than one object

Methods used by only one object.

lessons.title: Question 4
lessons.interactiveContent:
How can inheritance improve the code?

We can avoid unnecessary repetition of codeNothing can be improved

We can avoid unnecessary repetition of code.

lessons.title: Example 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Call drive() as a method of my_car to confirm that an inherited method can still be called as if it were the object's own.

Make sure to type drive().

lessons.title: Example 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Complete the code so that fido can use the bark() method from Dog.

Make sure to type Dog().

lessons.title: Example 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Pass in the correct objects so the code works properly.

Make sure to pick Dog.

lessons.title: Example 5
lessons.interactiveContent:
If the wizard is the only player that can cast spells, we can directly set a castSpell() method on Wizard instead of putting it in Player.

Make sure to pick def followed by castSpell and then (, self, ), :.

lessons.title: Classes recap
lessons.interactiveContent:
Classes contain a method called a constructor that sets the properties of new objects, known as instances.

Make sure to pick __init__.

lessons.title: Instances inherit methods
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can use the concept of inheritance to reuse parts of code in our classes, making our code more readable and efficient.

Make sure to pick person1 followed by . and then intro, (, ).

lessons.title: Student class
lessons.interactiveContent:
When working with classes, we have to think a bit about how to apply inheritance. Suppose we wanted to model a student class in our code.

Make sure to pick class, followed by Student:.

lessons.title: To create or not to create a new class
lessons.interactiveContent: We want Student to function like Person, except have a major. If we create a new Student class, we end up repeating the code from Person.

lessons.title: Creating subclasses
lessons.interactiveContent:
Instead, it makes more sense in this case to create a subclass that inherits Person's greet() method by coding (Person) after Student.

Make sure to pick (, followed by Person, and finally ).

lessons.title: Setting parent properties with super
lessons.interactiveContent:
To make sure Student will have the same properties as Person, we have to code super().__init__(name, age).

Make sure to pick super followed by ( and then ), ., __init__.

lessons.title: Setting parent properties with super 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Let's break down super().__init__(name, age). super refers to Student's parent class, Person.

Make sure to pick super, followed by (, and finally ).

lessons.title: Using super 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Then __init__ refers to Person's constructor. This allows us to use the existing constructor to set the name and age properties.

Make sure to pick __init__, followed by name, and finally age.

lessons.title: What's in a subclass instance?
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can now create objects that own properties and inherit methods from both Student and Person.

Make sure to pick student.major followed by greet and then (, ).

lessons.title: Question 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which class method sets the properties of instances?

__init__()init()

Make sure to pick __init__().

lessons.title: Question 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's missing from this code?

The year parameterThe major parameter

The year parameter.

lessons.title: Question 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does phone.call('Mom') display?

Calling MomAn error; phone.call is undefined

Calling Mom.

lessons.title: Question 4
lessons.interactiveContent:
A coworker needs objects with both company and language properties, so he creates a separate Developer class. What should he do instead?

Make Developer a subclass of EmployeeMake Employee set the language property

Make Developer a subclass of Employee.

lessons.title: Question 5
lessons.interactiveContent:
The dev instance is missing the company property. What line do we need to add to the Developer subclass?

super().__init__(company)self.company = company

Make sure to pick super().__init__(company).

lessons.title: Question 6
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which methods can we call on the jet instance?

Both fly() and invert()Only fly()

Both fly() and invert().

lessons.title: Example 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code the name of the method that sets the memory property on instances of the Computer class.

Make sure to type __init__.

lessons.title: Example 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a subclass called Laptop that inherits the turnOn() method from Computer.

Make sure to pick class followed by Laptop and then (, Computer, ), :.

lessons.title: Example 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Call super().__init__ with name and age so that instances of Parent receive these properties.

Make sure to pick super followed by ( and then ), ., __init__, (, name, age, ).

lessons.title: Example 4
lessons.interactiveContent:
Sally is a 40-year-old mother of two kids. Create a new instance that encapsulates her information.

Make sure to pick Parent followed by "Sally" and then 40, 2.

lessons.title: Example 5
lessons.interactiveContent:
Choose the correct class so that instances of Professor can receive both name and subject properties.

Make sure to type Teacher.

lessons.title: Example 6
lessons.interactiveContent:
Landline phones can make calls but can't surf the web. Choose the correct class for Landline to inherit.

Make sure to type Phone.
